review.title: Predicting Native Language from Gaze
review.abstract: A fundamental question in language learning concerns the role of a speaker's first language in second language acquisition. We present a novel methodology for studying this question: analysis of eye-movement patterns in second language reading of free-form text. Using this methodology, we demonstrate for the first time that the native language of English learners can be predicted from their gaze fixations when reading English. We provide analysis of classifier uncertainty and learned features, which indicates that differences in English reading are likely to be rooted in linguistic divergences across native languages. The presented framework complements production studies and offers new ground for advancing research on multilingualism.

sections.heading: 3 Native Language Identification from Reading
sections.text: Our first goal is to determine whether the native language of ESL learners can be deciphered from their viewing patterns when reading English text. We treat this question in two steps that correspond to our division of reading input into common and individual sentences. In the common scheme, all participants read the same sentences. By normalizing reading input, this scheme facilitates focusing on differences in reading behavior between readers. In the individual scheme, we use the individual batches of our data to tackle the more difficult variation of the NLIR task, where the reading material given to each participant is different.

sections.heading: 4 Analysis of Cross-Linguistic Influence in ESL Reading
sections.text: As mentioned in the previous section, the ability to read NLIR in general and the effectiveness of linguistically motivated traits in particular indicate that linguistic factors in the native and second languages are relevant for ESL reading. In this section, we will explore this hypothesis by analyzing the uncertainty of the classifiers and the traits learned in the NLIR task.

sections.heading: 4.1 Preservation of Linguistic Similarity
sections.text: Previous work in NLP suggested a link between textual patterns in ESL production and linguistic similarities of the respective native languages (Nagata and Whittaker, 2013; Nagata, 2014; Berzak et al., 2014, 2015). sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: Eyetracking and Second Language reading Second language reading has been studied using eyetracking, with much of the work focus on processing of syntactic ambiguities and analysisof specific target word classes as cognates (Dussias, 2010; Roberts and Siyanova-Chanturia, 2013). In contrast to our work, such studies typically use controlled, rather than freely formulated sentences. Investigation of global metrics in the form of second language reading was recently published by Cop et al. (2015). This study compares ESL and native reading of a novel by native Dutch speakers, observing longer sentence reading times, more fixations and shorter saccades in ESL reading. Unlike this study, our work focuses on comparing reading patterns between different native languages. We also analyze a related but different metric, namely speed, standardized fixation time of word sequences.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text: We show for the first time that this signal can be used to determine a reader's native language. In particular, the effectiveness of linguistic criteria for fixation clusters and our subsequent analysis suggest that the ESL reading process is influenced by linguistic factors. In particular, we show that linguistic similarities between native languages are reflected in similarities in ESL reading. We also identify several key features that characterize reading in different native languages and discuss their possible link to structural and lexical characteristics of native tongue. The presented results show that augmenting data can be helpful for the development of predictive and explanatory models of second language reading. While this work focuses on NLIR from fixations, our general framework can be used for additional aspects of reading, such as the analysis of saccades and eye trajectories.
